column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102416,2021,Technology Management,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CW Hagen', 'MJ Iwanczuk-Prost', 'prof.dr. DA Stam']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: For centuries, technology has been one of the most important pillars of the economy. Both in production-oriented sectors and in service companies, technology plays an important role. Without technological progress, companies will lose their competitive advantage. Managers have to face the question of how to make the most of technology. What technology is available and which technological innovations are developing? What might be the consequences of a technology for a company, a particular sector or society? What is the role of technology in the strategy of a company regarding its product/services, the production process and the core competencies? In short, how can managers recognize relevant technologies and properly implement them in a company? In this course, you will develop a technology strategy for one crucial high-end technology embedded in a core product of a case company by combining technological and business criteria.

The course is about the management of a company’s high-end technology that is embedded in one of the company’s core business or consumer products. The technology is an essential part of the product, but it may become outdated because of the rise of alternative technologies. These emerging technologies have the same functionality as the current technology, but may (in the future) add more value to the company’s core products and its customers. Therefore, the new technological developments need to be considered for sustainable competitiveness. It does not focus on the question of how to meet a short-term demand in the market by means of technology (market pull), but the focus will be on how an upcoming technology can be used in the longer run for redesigning products/services, production processes or core competencies of a company (technology push).

It is not evident that a company should always shift to the (technologically better) alternative. Introducing an emerging technology may have serious effects on the product, the production processes, the company at large, and the business environment. Therefore, managers should carefully evaluate and compare existing and emerging technologies and their effects. Therefore, the main question in this course is: should the company shift to an emerging technology, and if so to which one?

The aim of this course is to write a strategic plan for an existing company with high-tech products that could apply an alternative technology in one of its core products. In order to reach that goal, you have to analyse the company’s current situation (Assignment 0), compare the current technology with the emerging ones (Assignment 1), study the effects of emerging technologies on the company and its environment (Assignment 2), and combine this information into a proposal for a technology strategy (Assignment 3), which has to be summarized and presented during an executive presentation (Presentation).

The course can be related to SDG Goal 9: Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation. Part of assignment 2 and 3 is to consider the (societal) environment while thinking about the implementation of the emerging technologies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: • Manage (ones role in) an interdisciplinary, collaborative group.

• Communicate a strategic recommendation for a case company regarding their future use of technology

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101882,2021,Technology and Social Change,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. M Wehrle'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Technology evidently enables us to control, organize and optimize the activities and functions of our everyday lives. However, a classical critique in the Philosophy of Technology is that technology also creates a distance between us (as individuals), and the surrounding world. In this regard, the great developments in technology arguably lead to the illusion that everything around us is controllable, rendering us ‘safe’ at a distance. Other approaches focus instead on the mediating and connecting function of technology, which opens up new ways of experiencing and communicating. Some of the questions that motivate this course are: does technology really help us to disclose the world and connect with others, or rather does it alienate us from nature, others and even ourselves?  How is society affected by technology? Are we shaping technology or does technology shape us and our social lives?

To tackle these problems, we first have to ask what do we mean when we talk about ‘technology’. This implies a reflection on the development of technology and its changing meaning, function and role within society; from machines of mass production to virtual communication and the digital realm. This course offers an introduction into the different perspectives on how to understand the relationship between technology and the social lifeworld of human beings; to question, how do technological developments and social changes interact?

We will track the parallel changes of technologies and societies by starting with a historical reflection on the concept of technology and its relation to human nature, from Aristotle, to Bacon, Marx, Engels and Heidegger. On this basis, we will analyse influential approaches in Philosophy of Technology and recent STS like ‘technological determinism’ and ‘social constructivism’. Does technology controls and determines us, or do we socially construct technology instead through our specific needs and actions?
With Latour we will then critically question this antagonism, and explore the idea that we are just a tiny part in a broader network of various non-human and human actors.

We will then engage with (post)phenomenological accounts, who also emphasize the interrelation between humans, society and specific technologies. Instead of describing this interrelation objectively as network, they ask to what extent our subjective experience is mediated, extended  or even limited by technology.
Finally, we will discuss the political and ethical consequences of our interdependence with technology in focusing on the role of algorithms, digital environments and social media.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - To acquire basic knowledge of the concepts and debates (and their development) of the Philosophy of Technology, as well as, key perspectives in recent Science & Technology Studies (STS).
- To describe and analyze technological developments with regard to their relation to social changes.
- To compare and contrast the different kinds of scientific reasoning relevant to the Philosophy of Technology and technological sciences.
- To reflect critically on the assumptions, strengths and limitations of the different perspectives and concepts of technology.
- To apply this knowledge and analyze how technology and society mutually shape each other, with specific focus on the role of digital technologies.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The integration of new forms of technology and media into everyday life have begun to alter our sense of who we are and what we are about as human beings. Our sense of self – our identity – has shifted as ubiquitous technology and predictive algorithms become part of our social experiences. This is clearly evident in forms of social media, news and entertainment, but digitalisation has also changed the way we work, the way we shop, the way we date and the way we relate to our families. This course begins to explore these themes, starting with a clearer understanding of how social interaction and relationships produce and affect identity and how technology has become a mediating factor in our identity ‘constructions’. This is an incremental change from previous notions of self that were intimately attached to place, name and status or position. By focusing on media and technology, the course is intended to develop students’ critical self-reflective awareness of identity in the contemporary era and how media and technology affect the current and future shaping of self. The course draws on contemporary theories of identity, but also takes a practical approach by examining several domains in which identity is shaped. These domains take into consideration how technology and media are integrated into family and intimate relationships, workplaces, marketing, politics, entertainment, and news, giving grounding for a deeper understanding and awareness of identity in these contexts.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• the nature of identity theory as a field of social scientific study.

• the effects and influences of technology and media on identity.

column1: Students have the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • analyse how media and technology intersect with constructions of identity.

• Present and communicate their findings and viewpoints in writing, oral presentation, and discussion.
• Reflect on how media and technology is influencing their personal life.

column1: Today’s society is characterized by many as an information society. The industrial society, which was typical for the 19th and the first half of the 20th century, has transformed because of economic and cultural changes into a society in which information and information dissemination are central. The course technology democracy and society focusses on the role of modern ICT  within today’s society and in today’s democracy. The course will elaborate on which societal transformations are set in motion by the use of modern ICT and which consequences these societal transformations can have for the way in which ICT is used and perceived within society. Additionally topics such as chain information between organizations, interplay between technology and democracy and ethical issues will be discussed. In this course the main topics within the public sector related to technology will be addressed, among others, how big and open data influences the policy process, how computerized predictions can impact the way actors make decisions within matters in the public domain such as water management, climate change or safety and security and how this changes the dynamics of power within policy making, also we will address how the role of policy makers and those involved in the public sector changes into an information broker. Subsequently these changes have an effect on society and this effect will also be elaborated on.

De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding / For foreign students, English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After having followed the course, students are able to

column2: • Name which patterns and changes form the basis of today's information society
• Explain how dynamics within the policy process within the public sector change as a result of technology and the emergence of an information society and how this reflects on society
• Explain how public organizations and those employed there change as a result of technological change
• Explain how technology is applied in organizations and cooperation between organizations
• Name and reflect on ethical dilemmas regarding the use of technology

column1: Central in this course are research on television audiences and on audience reception. While many studies focus on the content of media, audience receptions of that content have been under-researched. Consequently, conclusions about media impact often remain rather speculative. In this course, we will explore how television audiences interpret and receive popular television genres and ‘texts’. We will pay attention, amongst other things, to the role played by social dimensions like race, ethnicity, gender, (dis)ability, social class, and religion in audience receptions. Television can be considered a powerful source for giving meaning to these social dimensions, while different viewers can negotiate and interpret these meanings in multiple ways.  Various forms of qualitative data-collection and data–analysis (e.g. individual interviews, focus groups, construction of topic list) will be discussed in order to prepare students to conduct independent research into television audiences. The assignments give students room to focus on TV genres/formats they are interested in. The various steps in the actual research process will be discussed and related to specific assignments in the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The interaction between media representations and audience receptions;
• Audience reception research, with a specific focus on popular television genres and social dimensions such as gender, race, ethnicity, religion;
• The different components of qualitative audience-related research and how these components relate to each other.
• Conduct qualitative audience research into TV audiences both individually and in teams.
• Reflect critically on methodological and theoretical articles in the field;

column1: Apply practical skills required for qualitative audience research, e.g. drafting a topic list, interviewing, qualitative data-analysis, presenting findings.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This is an exciting and transformative moment for television industries across the globe. As the economics of media industries shift from advertising-based revenue models to subscriber-based revenue models, video on-demand services that provide directly to consumers are becoming increasingly important. The growth of Disney+’s subscriber base to more than 100 million users in less than eighteen months, for example, demonstrates traditional players’ commitment to streaming distribution. Similarly, the global expansion of streaming platforms like Netflix are simultaneously reflections and drivers of change within the traditional television industries. To address these issues, this course uses a variety of interdisciplinary paradigms to understand television industries in the age of streaming.</body>

• Analyze and explain television industries in a variety of contemporary contexts.
• Reflect critically on the mainstream and academic discourses surrounding television industries.

column1: Dit practicum bouwt voort op de diverse practica waarin studenten kennis en ervaring hebben opgedaan van verschillende aspecten van het meer klinische werk als pedagoog. In dit practicum leer je om diagnostiek uit te voeren en daarbij oog te hebben op verschillende factoren die van invloed kunnen zijn op de ontwikkeling van een kind.

De studenten oefenen met het afnemen van diagnostische instrumenten bij een kind in de basisschoolleeftijd (bij voorkeur zonder ontwikkelingsproblemen). Daarnaast worden de gedragsontwikkeling en de (opvoed)omgeving in kaart gebracht. Als eindopdracht schrijft de student een klinisch onderzoeksverslag met ouders als doelgroep, zodat ze oefenen met het vertalen van onderzoeksresultaten naar leken. Daarnaast wordt er in de bijeenkomsten geoefend met het voeren van gesprekken met ouders over de onderzoeksresultaten. De testafname en/of het oudergesprek wordt geëvalueerd in een zelfreflectieverslag.

In het practicum wordt er duidelijk een connectie gemaakt met de klinische praktijk. De kennis en vaardigheden die in dit practicum worden opgedaan zijn een goede voorbereiding op de praktijkstage in de bachelor of master

column1: In an age where customer opinion and feedback can have an immediate, major effect upon the success of a business or organization, marketers must have the ability to analyze unstructured data in everything from social media and internet reviews to customer surveys or phone logs. This course provides students with tools that enable them to effectively implement and use text analytics in a marketing context. In the course the complete analysis process, from data input, summarizing and visualizing and rigorous statistical analysis, will be covered.
Next to the weekly lectures, students will make a group assignment to gain hands on experience with the techniques from the course.

column1: In this methodological course we will focus on analyzing primary sources. As the experiences and ideas of ordinary people are sporadically documented, historians use ego-documents, such as letters, diaries and oral sources as one, and sometimes even the only, way to capture this 'view from below'.

Students read and discuss literature on important debates concerning the use of primary sources such as biographies, letters, travel literature, songs, and visuals etc. in historical research; debates on the problematic notion of identity; and debates on notions such as discourse, focalization and argumentation as tools of narrative analysis, as well as on self-reflexivity. These notions are crucial to the application of narrative analysis as used in the course and are based on recent theoretical developments within history, anthropology, and postcolonial, minority, and subaltern studies.

The literature is read individually, and the assignments are discussed in sub-groups in class. The emphasis is on practicing con/text analysis on primary sources related to the master thesis of each student. For this purpose, each participant will bring along a printed version of an ego-document or another primary source related to the master thesis. During the course participants will discuss and practice the methodology of con/text analysis with respect to their own primary sources. The assignments are geared towards understanding the relation between primary sources, the methodological and theoretical framework used, and the analytical findings in historical research. Each participant writes two essays (midterm and final) in which he or she reflects on the theoretical as well as practical aspects of analyzing the selected primary source ‘against the grain’.
Note: Students who have successfully completed ""Narrative Analysis, Orality, and Biography"" (CH4107) in previous years can not register for this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column5: • Students can critically evaluate scholarship on narrative and visual analysis in written and oral reports.
• Students can demonstrate the relevance of theoretical concepts like discourse, identity, and focalization in relation to the primary sources used in their Master’s Thesis.
• Students are able to analyze oral, written, visual, and auditory primary source material ‘against the grain’.
• Students can critically assess their influence in the analysis of the primary source in relation to the Master’s Thesis main research question.

column1: <body>Each week, you will perform an R assignment based on an online video tutorial. The video tutorials will be accessible via Canvas. You will perform the assignments at home on your personal computer (pc or mac). The first tutorial will introduce you to the basic functionalities of RStudio. Each of the three subsequent video tutorials will guide you through a specific aspect of the Twitter research flow. In the second tutorial you will learn how to independently collect a large dataset of Twitter messages (i.e., tweets and complementary information). The third tutorial will show you how to preprocess the data and how to perform a sentiment classification (i.e. how to classify Twitter messages into ‘positive’ and ‘negative’ categories). The final tutorial will guide you to analyze your results and produce descriptive and inferential statistics and figures.</body>

column1: <body>The purpose of this practicum is twofold: you will learn how to use R and you will independently perform a comprehensive research procedure involving the investigation of (text-based) Twitter data.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98946,2021,The Art of Choosing: Making choices that maximize happiness,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. J Boegershausen'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Choices ranging from the mundane to the profound are an essential part of our daily life. Just consider how many choices you already made today before you started reading this description. At a more fundamental level, being able to decide for ourselves can provide a sense of control and autonomy that is essential to well-being and human flourishing. Yet how to make choices that make us happy, provide purpose, and allow us to enhance our quality of life often remains elusive.

In this course, we will deconstruct choice and why it matters so much. We will explore whether there ever can be too much choice and the myriad influences that context has on our decisions and choices. At the end of the course, you will be able to leverage these insights to make better choices for the good of yourself and others.

Understanding and overcoming our own biases and shortcomings in choice may not only increase happiness but also can also facilitate being a force for positive change. In the words of Aristotle, “knowing yourself is the
beginning of all wisdom”. This course is designed to equip you with frameworks and tools to craft and curate
compelling customer experiences that facilitate better choices for consumers and firms alike.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: Understand how choices influence different forms of happiness
Identify and analyze relevant situational influences that might shape choice
Engage in critical self-reflection about your own decisions
Learn how we can make better choices for ourselves and others
Evaluate different approaches to curate choice sets and assortments that create value for consumers and firms

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100024,2021,The Art of Filmmaking,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N Ozgenalp', 'prof.dr. CJM van Eijck']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: When studying art and culture, film is one cultural discipline that demands our attention. In all its diversity, film is an extremely popular art form. It constitutes a major industry and its stories, characters, and taglines have found their way into mainstream culture. In this course, we explore the art of filmmaking from various academic perspectives. We discuss the historical development of cinema as an entertainment industry as well as film as an art product. We learn to use and read film grammar and analyse filmic content. We discuss major topics in film criticism and film theory. Finally, we consider the reception and effect of films within their social, cultural, and political contexts.
Attending the weekly lectures is strongly advised, but not mandatory. Please make sure you arrive on time.
The aims of the lectures are multifold:
- To sketch the broad outlines of the weekly course subjects, thereby largely following the outlines of the provided literature;
- To investigate selected key aspects of the course subjects deeper, mainly by means of case studies on specific films and excerpts from the contemporaneous writings;
- To illustrate the course subjects and the case-studies by means of clips from movies and documentaries;
- To learn and practice the analysis of the moving image and its meaning-making mechanisms;
- To learn film grammar through key concepts introduced every week in relation to the topic of the lecture;
- To acquire a critical approach to the established narratives of cinema culture and history.
The lecture slides will be published on Canvas after the lecture.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students gain insight into film history, film presentation, film production techniques, world cinema industries, film grammar, methods of film analysis and key concepts in film theory. They learn to consider this popular art form from different academic perspectives.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100391,2021,The Avant-Garde: Experimental Art, Photography and Film",Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Avant-Garde is the French military term for front-guard and is generally used to describe the most adventurous manifestations of modern art, photography and film. Art – in the broadest sense of the word - that forges ahead, breaks down barriers and challenges the status quo, but at the same time, art that is difficult, sometimes incomprehensible and elitist. Through a combination of the humanities and sociological perspectives, we will trace the roots of the Avant-Garde, examine the challenges that avant-garde artists faced and discuss whether avant-garde art is still possible today.

The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between the visual arts (i.e. fine arts, photography, film) and society from – roughly - 1850 to the present. Students will become familiar with the most influential visions on avant-garde art, the most influential critiques of avant-garde art, and the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art. Students will be able to think, write and talk about avant-garde art in its historical and social context; research appropriate literature; and create self-formulated questions.

All this will lead up to a symposium that we will organise at the end of the course, during which students will present and discuss short papers about the several themes that we discussed during our lectures and museum visits.

column3: The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between the visual arts and society for approximately the last 150 years. Students will become familiar with the most influential visions on avant-garde art, the most influential critiques of avant-garde art, and the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art. Students will be able to think, write and talk about avant-garde art in its historical and social context; research appropriate literature; and create self-formulated questions.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98485,2021,The Brain,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. KA Sikora', 'drs. AB Boot, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The brain: maybe the most important organ of our body. Without the brain we would not be aware of anything around us. The world would not exist for us. It’s not our eyes that make us see, it’s not our ears that make us hear. It is only in our brain were we become aware of what we see and what we hear. In this course you will learn about this exciting organ, the brain, with its neural circuits giving rise to psychological functions like cognition and emotion.

Everything that happens in the brain is the result of interactions between brain cells, the neurons. Neurons communicate with each other through chemical substances. In this block you will learn how this communication takes place and what happens when this communication goes wrong in clinical disorders like depression and schizophrenia. You will also learn how the brain develops, how neural circuits arise and how these are subject to modifications as a result of experience.

Brain research is constantly giving us new ideas about how the brain works and what happens when things seem to go wrong in the brain. There are still many things that we (or better ‘science’) do not exactly know about the brain. This makes it a very exciting topic to study. If everything would be known already, it would be less fun. Actually, some say that we might never be able to understand the brain completely. As L. Watson, a well-known scientist, said:
”If the brain were so simple we could understand it, we would be so simple we couldn't.”

Indeed, brain is a comprehensive subject.  You will learn a lot of new names and terms and this might be a little confusing in the beginning. When you feel like this, just think of the following quote from another scientist, W. Rogers:
“You know you've got to exercise your brain just like your muscles"".</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of this course, you will have a deeper understanding of

column2: •          the cellular basis of brain functioning and neural circuits (including the role and working of neurotransmitters and receptors, and the cascade that the binding of a neurotransmitter to a receptor sets off).
•          how neural circuits arise in the development of the brain.
•          how modifications of neural circuits take place as a result of experience and learning
•         the biological basis of brain dysfunctions (e.g. psychiatric disorders) and the working of psychotropic drugs
•         the process of recovery after brain damage, involving neuroplasticity

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100127,2021,The Business of Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The media sector is an important economic industry that is increasingly expanding into other sectors such as healthcare or connected vehicles. During this course we focus  on the  media  firm as  our unit of analysis  and we will use the  business  model canvas  as  our main   analytical model.

During the classes we will discuss how media firms design value  propositions, engage with customers, produce content and services (value chains), manage their organizations and generate revenues. We will address the impact of new (digital) media technologies on the business models of media firms. Furthermore, we will also look at specific business related issues that media firms face in specific sectors, such as TV, gaming and digital video. We will also address how government policy impacts business models of media firms, for instance around copyrights, privacy and competition law.

An important part of this course consists of guest lectures by people that work in media companies. These guest lecturers will familiarize students with real life experiences around the topics that will be discussed.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 60. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Theoretical approaches, key concepts and current developments in the field of media business and media management;
• The operations of contemporary media organizations from a management and business perspective;
• Read, critique, and apply relevant theoretical concepts to specific business related issues faced by media firms
• Analyze and critically reflect upon the use of business models by media firms

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Climate Crisis: Ecology, Economy & Politics in the Anthropocene
There is consensus among scientists in fields that are contributing to the study of climate change
that mankind has a negative impact on our climate and that we are rapidly running out of time to
avert a catastrophically changed climate. Still we mankind, as a whole - do not seem to be in a
hurry to change the ways in which we have organised our everyday lives, our economies and our
societies. Why? And what is to be done?
In this course we discuss the ways in which we shape the climate and the climate has shaped, and
will continue to shape, us from the very distant past to the not so distant future. By combining
perspectives from philosophical anthropology, psychology, political economy and (geo)politics
students get a thorough introduction into the problematic of climate change. Throughout the
course we pay particular attention to the concept of the Anthropocene as well as its uses and
abuses in popular discourse and academic disciplines as varied as climate sciences, geology, social

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Have a basic understanding of the causes and consequences of Climate Change;
• Have a basic understanding of the debate about the (use and abuse of the term) Anthropocene;
• Have a basic understanding of economic solutions to climate change;
• Have a basic understanding of the politics of climate change;
• Have a basic understanding of the pros and cons of technological fixes;
• Have a basic understanding of the SF mode in both its literary and theoretical sense;
• Have an advanced understanding of the work of key thinkers on Climate Change such as Latour and Haraway, Moore and Giddens and Morton and Jonas.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The main objective of this course is to familiarize students with key concepts and major perspectives – developments, trends, and problems – in the economics of art and culture. The course will present the cultural economic perspective as developed by David Throsby, Bruno Frey, Arjo Klamer and other economic sociologists and contrast this with the standard economic approach to the arts and culture. The central question is how artists, consumers and cultural organizations realize the social and cultural values of art and culture. Another central theme is how cultural goods are priced and valued in the economy, within society, and within the art world. Special attention will be given to the role of digital technology in the process of valuation and pricing of the arts and culture. During the lectures these issues will be discussed from a theoretical perspective, while the workgroups will focus on the application of these theories to concrete economic phenomena or from the world of arts and culture that are familiar to students from their everyday life.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The goal of this course is to familiarize students with what has come to be called the cultural economic perspective. After this course students should be able to identify the differences between this perspective and the standard economic perspective, and they are expected to be able to analyze various phenomena using the cultural economic perspective.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101895,2021,The High Enlightenment I,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. L van Bunge'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

By 1750s the French Enlightenment in particular takes off its gloves. Diderot and D’Holbach start propagating a ‘Spinozist’ materialism, which raises the issue of the origins of the Radical Enlightenment. Simultaneously Rousseau singlehandedly revolutionizes French political thought. Meanwhile, the German Enlightenment (Thomasius, Wolff, Lessing) gets under way and the eighteenth-century culture of sensibility spreads throughout Europe. Following the French Revolution, Burke and De Maistre launch their Counter-Enlightenment, the echoes of which can still be traced in twentieth-century critical accounts of the Enlightenment such as Adorno and Horkheimer’s Dialectics of Enlightenment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To fulltime students of Philosophy the seminars are compulsory.

Having completed this course, students will be familiar with some of the main ideas put forward by D’Holbach and the so-called ‘radical Enlightenment’. They will understand the main characteristics of Rousseau’s thought. They will be able to distinguish some of the key differences between the French and the German Enlightenment. They will know some of the most important critical assessments of the Enlightenment, put forward during the late eighteenth and the twentieth centuries.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101896,2021,The High Enlightenment II: Kant,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['D Rusu', 'dr. P Schuurman']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: David Hume’s criticism of the notion of causality prompted Immanuel Kant to develop a new philosophy in which causality is no longer a property of the world outside us, but rather a concept in our minds that assists us in making sense of the world. This is his famous ‘Copernican Revolution’; rather than objects in the world shaping the cognitive operations of subjects (epistemological realism), these subjective operations determine our perceptions of objects and our judgements about objects (epistemological idealism). This is only part of Kant’s enormous contribution to philosophy. In his ethics he defended morality in the form of a law that demands to be obeyed for its own sake, the commands of which are not issued by some alien authority but the voice of reason that the moral subject can recognize as his own.

Finally, although Kant was a great Enlightened demolisher of the truth of metaphysics, he nevertheless maintained that certain notions can still have a useful regulative function; one example is the notion of teleology. This notion plays a major role in his philosophy of history, his political philosophy and his radical plea for world peace, Perpetual Peace (1795); paradoxically enough, this teleological perspective also implies a surprisingly positive evaluation of the function of war.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To fulltime students of Philosophy the seminars are compulsory.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This module provides an introduction to the development of the international political system from 1500 to the present. The focus is on the highest, systemic level: the practice of international politics, its main actors, the rules, assumptions, understandings and norms that underpinned said practice, and how all of these changed over time. Particular attention will be paid to key moments in international history, such as peace conferences, global encounters, major wars and international institution-building, from the encounters of separate civilisations in the 1500s to today’s global governance.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1.       Students will be able to analyse the evolution of the international system since 1500;
2.       Students will be able to evaluate theoretical perspectives on the role of ideas versus power in shaping international order since 1500;
3.       Students will be able to originate a response paper critically assessing current claims about the future of the international system in the twenty-first century.

JF Gerber', 'dr. RBC Huijsmans', 'E Papyrakis', 'M Cadaval Narezo', 'N Wagner', 'prof.dr. M Arsel', 'prof.dr. P Knorringa', 'prof.dr. RA Icaza Garza', 'prof.dr. W Harcourt', 'prof.mr.dr. <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course is a critical introduction to theories and strategies of international development – looking at the making, unmaking and remaking of development from cultural, historical, and political economic perspectives. It aims building a dialogue between the students’ own experiences and knowledges of development with the different approaches of the course literature from development studies and beyond. The three modules focus on: narratives of economic development; people and places in development; and post development and alternatives to development. Emphasis will be on the analyses of development as a historical process, an aspiration, a discourse of power and set of practices and in engaging students in critical approaches to development as a study and as a practice. The course fosters an open learning environment using participatory interactive methodology in order to encourage co-learning knowledge generation. The course features interactive lectures, a group produced video essay and student-led workshops.
Cornwall, A. and D. Eade, eds. (2010) Deconstructing Development Discourse: Buzzwords and Fuzzwords. Warwickshire: Practical Action Publishing.
Escobar, A. (1995) Encountering Development. Princeton: Princeton University Press.
McKinnon, K.(2011) Development Professionals in Northern Thailand: Hope, Politics and Power. Singapore, ASAA Southeast Asia Publications Series, Singapore University Press.
Mosse, D. (2005). Cultivating Development: An ethnography of aid policy and practice. London, Ann Arbor (MI): Pluto Press.
Oyeronke, O. (1997) The Invention of Women. Making an African Sense of Western Gender Discourses. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press.
Rist, G. (2003) The History of Development: From Western Origins to Global Faith. London: Zed Books.
Sachs, W. (1992/2010) The Development Dictionary: a guide to knowledge as power. London: Zed Books.
Sen, A. (1999) Development as Freedom. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
De Sousa Santos, B. Epistemologies of the South. Justice Against Epistemicide. Boulder: Paradigm Publishers/
AV: “The Danger of the Single Story” http://www.ted.com/talks/chimamanda_adichie_the_danger_of_a_single_story?language=en

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This course can only be taken as part of the LDE programme track ‘Migration and Development’
During the course the students will acquire a critical lens through which to analyze development by being able to:
a) Unpack development as a contested set of cultural, political, economic and historical processes and relations
b) Appraise how ‘development problems’ and ‘solutions’ are understood according to different conceptual approaches to development
c) Reflect critically on their own understanding of and encounters with development
d) Work collaboratively within a multidisciplinary and multicultural context to communicate ideas about the making of development visually, orally and in writing.
e) Engage in a critical dialogue on development studies with peers and staff

column1: The course is a conversation and confrontation between the work of Jan Tinbergen and contemporary literature on economics and philosophy. This conversation is organized around three themes which will each be covered in two sessions. These four themes are Econometric Expertise for Policymaking, Measurement of Welfare and Symmetric modelling and asymmetrical modelling.
A maximum of one seminar can be missed. If two are missed the student has to make compensatory assignments. Missing more than two seminars leads to exclusion from the course.

ESE students from the master Economics & Business may follow this course as a (free) elective. However, as there are limited places available in this course, ESE students need to write a short motivation letter to sign-up. In this motivation letter, you explain why you are interested in the Philosophy and Economics of Jan Tinbergen and what you expect to bring to the classroom. Send your motivation to the course lecturer, Dr. Erwin Dekker, (dekker.erwin@gmail.com) by 8 October 2021 the latest.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course examines practical and theoretical issues concerning European Integration and touches upon legal and economic implications of the European Union: What is the political background of European Integration? How does it affect us in daily life? Is it possible to preserve a country’s specificities, like culture or social security, while at the same time benefitting from more economic exchange?

column2: • A trip to Brussels to visit the European institutions and meet EU decision makers
• Lecturers with different backgrounds of expertise in European matters
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Getting a principal understanding of economic integration. This implies a basic understanding of international trade and federalism. But also the interrelation between the political process and economic integration will be discussed.

• The historical and legal background of European integration will be presented. The students will be acquainted with the constitutional principles of the EU as well as specific sector policies (e.g. competition policy and agricultural policy).
• From the viewpoint of their own academic background and experience, the students shall write a short term paper on a European integration issue.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100027,2021,The Popular Music Hit Song Project,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JCF Schaap', 'W Coppes, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In this hands-on project-course, students will work together with Codarts students to fabricate a ‘hit’ song. This course aims to have students submerged in the ‘real-life’ practice of popular music production and distribution. This does not only involve the making of the music itself (including recording and production), but especially the social and industry practices discussed in the other courses of the minor programme. This means that students will set a goal for their hit (e.g. mainstream or underground scene) and work on getting the song ‘out there’ through the right channels, (social) media and – hopefully – (online) stages. These projects are presented in a final symposium at the end of the minor. Students will have weekly project meetings at Codarts (Rotterdam-West), supported by multiple coaches from the field of contemporary music production. Rehearsal spaces and studio time will be made available by Codarts. Students are expected to show a high level of independence and academic maturity to bring this course to completion.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is exclusively for students enrolled in the minor ‘MU$IC: The economy, sociology, and practice of popular music’. In this project-course, students will work together with Codarts students to fabricate a ‘hit’ song. After following this course, students can creatively apply their knowledge on the sociology and economy of music in musical entrepreneurship, will have an in-depth understanding of the production and distribution of contemporary ‘hit’ songs and can apply this in practice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course presents a concise overview of financial markets. This includes coverage of a wide array of financial assets, the risks associated with their use, various trading mechanisms employed by exchanges and different forms of organization that govern the interaction among market participants. This will provide students with a solid foundation for understanding the continually evolving financial system, its institutions, its markets, and its products.

We start with an overview of the financial system and talk about the functions of financial markets and institutions. We describe the financial institutions industry and pay special attention to the mutual fund industry. We cover the basic features of (1) the money markets (2) the bond market (3) the stock market (4) the mortgage markets (5) the foreign exchange market and (6) cryptocurrencies. We touch upon valuation of different financial assets, risk assessment, behavior of the financial asset users and implications of the financial market on the economy as a whole.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the fundamental concepts of financial markets and market participants.
• Identify and analyze features of financial products developed in various financial markets.
• Apply theories to explain and predict changes in valuation of various financial products.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102747,2021,The Principle and Function of Reason,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. S van Tuinen'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Anthropocene marks a seismic shift in the relation between thinking and being. In the face of the many threats to what we consider ‘reasonable’, this module revisits the first principle of ‘modern’ rational thought and deliberation, the Principle of Sufficient Reason (PSR): the demand for an intelligible ground for every fact. It has long been understood as the theoretical a priori through which human thought grounds existence in thought itself. Galilei suggested that all of nature obeys mathematical laws; Spinoza demanded that God coincides with his understandability; Hegel claimed that ‘the real is the rational and the rational is the real.’ In this perspective, we would always have lived in an idealized Anthropocene, and consciously so for at least half a millennium!

The irony is that, in the real Anthropocene, human reason and the material conditions of its existence are seen to diverge. From the brain to AI and from the economy to the planet at large, we are beginning to realize that the mind inhabits grounds that are not ‘for us’ and that can exist without us. The growing a-synchronicity between human beings and ever more captivating and pervasive technologies renders obsolete the enlightenment ideal of the human as self-aware, knowing, thinking and feeling ‘I’. What counts as reasonable – and what circulates as ‘reason’ – in this new state of nature mediated by technology and capital?

The aim of this course module is 1) to become acquainted with the main critiques and traditional defenses of the PSR as well as 2) to explore possibilities for reclaiming it. It will involve guest lectures, close-reading and ample room for debate.

1. In the first part we explore an internalist interpretation of the PSR, in which the ground is posited as internal to reason, the PSR is really the principle of necessary reason (PNR). This interpretation is introduced through the classical interpretations by Heidegger, Derrida and Lyotard as well as through recent takes in analytical philosophy. It is then developed historically through readings of Spinoza and Hegel, and subjected to critique through readings of Marcuse and Deleuze.

2. In the second part we develop a less known, externalist interpretation, according to which the PSR finds its necessity in the experience of groundlessness (insufficient reason), in situations where there is no evident answer to questions such as ‘why this here now?’ or ‘by what right?’ We initially look for this interpretation in the work of Whitehead and Stiegler, then develop it historically through readings of Leibniz and Schelling, in order to ultimately wrap up this new sense of the PSR with Serres and yours truly.

According to Kant, the PSR, which has been ‘often sought, but always in vain’, has passed through three historical stages: dogmatism, skepticism, critique. But do recent developments in science and technology studies, feminist ethics, community organizing, and environmentalism not rather indicate that we have entered a fourth, contemporary stage in the life of the mind, that of care?

column1: To acquire a solid grasp of the history of the concept of the principle of sufficient reason (PSR).
To be able to recognize the different stakes in appeals to ‘reason’ in both public and academic discourse.
To recognize various diverging and sometimes mutually contradicting uses of the PSR.
To apply and reorient the PSR in relation to pressing contemporary problems in the ecology of mind</body>

column1: <body>This course teaches students how they can use their academic skills and knowledge in society. Historians have specific skills which enables them to contribute to public debates or which are useful in professional contexts. Politicians and policy advisors realize more and more that knowledge about the past can be important to understand the contemporary world. Governments use the past to shape collective identities and to strengthen social cohesion. History education is often used to promote active citizenship, but historical museums and television series are also mobilized to create shared identities. Historians use a conceptual framework to assess the impact of the past on contemporary developments and to make useful historical comparisons. They are also capable to qualify and deepen the use of the past in popular culture, such as the heritage and the entertainment industry.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course has four main objectives. Firstly, students can communicate scientific knowledge to a broad public. This implies that they are capable to bridge the gap between academic ethics and concrete expectations from consumers. Students are also able to analyze societal challenges from a contemporary and historical perspective. Finally, students can evaluate different forms of public history and they can communicate their assessment in oral and written reports.</body>

column1: The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4, preparing the students for writing their master’s thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, then students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:
-  discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  critical discussion of the research proposals
-  discussion of and information on possible research methods
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  presentation of the thesis research at master conference in June 2018
The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4.
Theme: The US in a Changing World Order

The rise of the United States as a global power has been one of the defining features of the twentieth century. Throughout the decades, the US has molded the international system in the attempt to create one in its own likeness. This seminar will help the students to reckon with the complex history of US’s positioning in the contemporary world and its varied entanglements in world affairs.

Chronologically, the seminar will mostly focus on the twentieth century. Thematically, it will delve deeper into the various political, cultural, social, and economic dynamics that have shaped both the American foreign policy making process and its outcomes. The seminar will therefore touch on such crucial themes as exceptionalism, empire, Wilsonianism, multilateral diplomacy, world order, hegemony, resistance, and predominance of power. Eventually, the seminar will also sketch out the most important challenges that the US – due its crystallized global leadership – faces in our current days.

By adopting a historical perspective, thus by letting students explore the linchpins of the historiographical debate on US foreign policy and by simultaneously inviting them to critically engage with relevant primary sources, the seminar will provide a broad overview of the US role in the world during the twentieth century (and beyond), and it will stress the transnational nature of the American nation and the structural interdependence it contributed to establishing on a global scale.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October

column1: This first course in the Politics & Society specialisation familiarises students with the sociological study of politics, focusing on social patterns in public attitudes and political behaviour. How can we understand social differences in support for various value orientations, ideologies, and political parties? And how can we explain social inequalities in political trust and political involvement, both in the formal political domain and in non-institutional politics? There has been a marked decline in Western societies from the 1960s onwards in encompassing political ideologies and the political salience of classic group identities such as classes and religions – a process often referred to as individualisation. This does, however, not imply that value conflicts, voting behaviour, and participation in social movements are no longer socially shaped. On the contrary: old social fault lines have given way to new ones. Systematically combining theories from both sociology and political science with findings from empirical research, this course addresses the contemporary political relevance of these social cleavages. What are their present-day implications? Which groups currently clash over which issues, why is this the case, and how is this related to support for political parties? How can we interpret social differences in anti-immigrant sentiments, political trust, voter turnout, and political protest? And how are these political attitudes and behaviours influenced by online and offline social networks?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Discuss the political salience of old and new social divisions and cleavages;
• Formulate and explain social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours;
• Analyse social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours and apply these to contemporary social phenomena;
• Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102546,2021,Theatre of the Human,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. GH van Oenen'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

We ask how the sciences of man and of the social perceive what is human and how it is situated in the world. Man and world are not universal, static givens but particular, dynamics products of a multitude of forces and institutions that we usually classify as e.g. economic, social, political, cultural, psychological, historical, architectural, ecological. These perspectives are each tied up with (modern) sciences that propose and legitimate conceptions of both the human and the world. Philosophical anthropology both competes with these perspectives, and aims to bring them together, in a continuing attempt to understand how the human relates to the world and how this is expressed in human self-understanding.

In this course, we will investigate this relation as a ‘theatre of the human’: the human is something performed, performing, and performative, acting within, and out of, the conditions and affordances of the world as he (mis)understands, appropriates, incorporates, and abnegates them. The sciences of man and of the social, to be sure, do not just study, describe, and explain this theatre; they are performative as well, in their representation of the theatrical structure and their rendering of the human and the world. The sciences, in other words, are themselves part of the theatre of the human.
